Physical Measurements
caption: Understand the basics of measuring physical quantities, units, and the tools used to obtain accurate data.
intro: Measurements are fundamental in learning about physical quantities for everything. For example, if we have an amount of apples, we cannot determine its mass without comparing it to a known kilogram mass. Measurements allow us to translate our everyday observations into quantitative terms expressed in numbers.
goals:
• What is the physical quantities.
  • Who to measure this quantities.
  • What is the meaning of units.
  • What is the Standard formula.
details:
Measurement Errors and Types of Measurement

Measurement Errors Can Be Caused By:

  • Choosing Improper Tool: Like using an ordinary balance instead of a sensitive balance when measuring the mass of a golden ring.
  • A Defect in the Measuring Tool:
    • Defects in an ammeter, such as a partially demagnetized magnet because it is outdated.
    • The pointer has a zero error when there is no electric current.
  • Wrong Procedure Due to Unexperienced Persons:
    • Ignorance of using graduated devices like multimeters.
    • Looking at the device pointer or scale at an oblique angle instead of perpendicularly.
  • Environmental Conditions: Such as:
    • temperature
    • humidity
    • air currents
      • For example: when using a sensitive balance, air currents may cause an error, so the balance is kept inside a glass box.

Types of Measurement:

  • Direct Measurement: It is a way of measuring using a single tool. For example: measuring density using a hydrometer.
  • Indirect Measurement: It is a way of measuring using more than one tool. For example: measuring the density of a liquid by measuring the mass using a balance, then measuring the volume using a graduated cylinder, and then dividing the mass by the volume.

title: Types of Measurement & Measurement Error
caption: Learn about different types of measurements, including common errors and how to minimize them.
intro: Technological development throughout history has always been associated with the accuracy of the measurement process. However, there is no measurement process that has 100% accuracy. There is always the possibility of an error, so we should calculate it.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:
  • Know the reasons for measurement error and how to reduce it.
  • Know the difference between direct and indirect error.
  • define absolute measurement error.
  • define the accepted value of a measurement.
  • define relative measurement error.
  • calculate relative measurement error and absolute error.
details:
Measurement Errors and Types of Measurement

Measurement Errors Can Be Caused By:

  • Choosing Improper Tool: Like using an ordinary balance instead of a sensitive balance when measuring the mass of a golden ring.
  • A Defect in the Measuring Tool:
    • Defects in an ammeter, such as a partially demagnetized magnet because it is outdated.
    • The pointer has a zero error when there is no electric current.
  • Wrong Procedure Due to Unexperienced Persons:
    • Ignorance of using graduated devices like multimeters.
    • Looking at the device pointer or scale at an oblique angle instead of perpendicularly.
  • Environmental Conditions: Such as:
    • temperature
    • humidity
    • air currents
      • For example: when using a sensitive balance, air currents may cause an error, so the balance is kept inside a glass box.

Types of Measurement:

  • Direct Measurement: It is a way of measuring using a single tool.
    • For example: measuring density using a hydrometer.
  • Indirect Measurement: It is a way of measuring using more than one tool.
    • For example: measuring the density of a liquid by measuring the mass using a balance, then measuring the volume using a graduated cylinder, and then dividing the mass by the volume.

title: Scalar and Vector Quantities
caption: Differentiate between scalar and vector quantities and their significance in physics.
intro: In our study of physics, we found Some physical quantities, such as time, temperature, mass, and density, can be described completely by a single number with a unit. But many other important quantities in physics have a direction associated with them and cannot be described by a single number.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:
  • What is the Scalar & Vector quantities.
  • How to represent a vector.
  • What is the vector algebra.
details:
physical quantities can be classified into:

  • Scalar quantities: It is a physical quantity that can be fully defined by its magnitude only. It has no direction.
    • For example:
    • Distance
    • Mass
    • Time
    • Temperature
    • Energy
  • Vector quantities: It is a physical quantity that can be fully defined by both magnitude and direction.
    • For example:
    • Displacement
    • Acceleration
    • Velocity
    • Force
Now, we talk about a common example of a similar and very close scaler and vector quantities that many got confused about them which are:
  • Distance (S) It is a physical quantity that can be fully defined by its magnitude only. It has no direction.
  • Displacement (d) It is a physical quantity that can be fully defined by both magnitude and direction.

title: Motion and Velocity
caption: Explore the fundamental concepts of motion and speed, understanding how objects move and how their velocities are measured.
intro: From everyday experience, we recognize that the motion of an object represents a continuous change in the object’s position.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:
  • Know the motion types.
  • Understand position and velocity
  • Know the difference between speed and velocity
  • Know the types of velocity.
details:
In physics, we can categorize motion into:

  1. Translational motion: It is the motion which is characterized by having a starting point and an end point.
    2. Example:
    • Motion in a straight line.
    • Motion in a curved path (projectiles).
  2. Periodic motion: It is the motion that repeats itself over equal intervals of time.
    3. Example:
    • Circular motion.
    • Viberational motion

In this year, we will only focus on translational motion,

  1. Postion

    To describe the motion of an object, we must be able to specify the location of the object at all time (𝐭) , so you must understand displacement and distance before delving into the next topic

  2. Velcoity

    Bodies around us move, some appear slow, and some appear fast, but these descriptions are not scientifically accurate.To understand the meaning of "velocity" study the following motion diagram, we notice that the runner changes his position with time. If we record the displacement data at each second, we will obtain a table of data.

To represent the relationship between displacement (on the vertical axis) and time (on the horizontal axis), we can:

  1. Draw a vertical line passing through the point (1 s) on the time axis.
  2. Draw a horizontal line passing through the point (5) on the displacement axis.
  3. Identify the point of intersection between the vertical and horizontal lines.
  4. Repeat the above steps with the remaining time and displacement points.
  5. Draw the best straight line passing through the intersection points.
  6. Determine the slope of the straight line to calculate the velocity.

title: Acceleration
caption: Delve into the concept of acceleration, the rate at which an object's velocity changes over time, and its impact on motion.
intro: If the velocity of an object is changed from one point to another either in magnitude or in direction, this change in velocity with time is known as acceleration (𝒂).
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:
  • Know what is acceleration.
  • Know the types of acceleration.
details:
Acceleration :
It is the change of the object’s velocity per unit time.
OR
It is the rate of change of velocity.
$$ 𝒂 =\frac{𝒗_𝟐−𝒗_𝟏}{𝒕_2− 𝒕_1}=\frac{𝚫𝒗}{𝚫𝒕} $$

Types of acceleration

Uniform Acceleration :
The acceleration in which the object changes its velocity with equal amounts in equal time intervals. It is represented by straight line in a $𝒗−𝒕$ graph. $$𝒂 = slope =\frac{𝒗_𝟐−𝒗_𝟏}{𝒕_𝟐−𝒕_𝟏}$$
Non-Uniform Acceleration :
The acceleration in which the object changes its velocity with unequal amounts in equal time intervals. It is represented by curved line in a 𝒗−𝒕 graph. $$𝒂 = slope\ of\ the\ tangent$$

title: Equations of Motion
caption: Learn the key equations that describe the motion of objects, providing a mathematical framework for predicting future positions and velocities.
intro: There are equations that govern the motion of a body when the velocity changes at the same rate throughout the motion (constant acceleration), these equations are called Equations of Motion.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:
  • be able to derive the equations of motion.
  • Use the equations to determine, initial velocity, final velocity, displacement, or time.
details:
First equation: equation of (Velocity–Time)

If we have an object that starts its motion with initial velocity \(𝒗_𝒊\) and have acceleration \(𝒂\) and reaches a final velocity \(𝒗_𝒇 \) after a time \(𝚫 𝒕\).

We know that the uniform acceleration \(𝒂\) is given by the relation :

$$𝒂=\frac{𝜟𝒗}{𝜟𝒕}$$

If the object starts motion at \(𝒕=𝟎\),

$$∴\ 𝜟𝒕=𝒕−𝟎=𝒕 $$ $$𝜟𝒗=𝒗_𝒇−𝒗_𝒊 \ \hspace{1cm} \Rightarrow ∴ 𝒂=\frac{𝒗_𝒇−𝒗_𝒊}{𝒕} \Rightarrow 𝒂𝒕=𝒗_𝒇−𝒗_𝒊$$
$$ 𝒗_𝒇=𝒗_𝒊+𝒂𝒕 $$
Second equation: equation of (Displacement–Time)

We know that average velocity \(𝒗\) is given by the relation:

$$ \bar{v}=\frac{d}{t} \hspace{1cm} OR \hspace{1cm} \bar{v}=\frac{v_f+v_i}{2} $$ $$ \therefore \frac{d}{t}=\frac{v_f+v_i}{2} $$

From the first equation of motion,

$$ \therefore \frac{d}{t}=\frac{\left(v_i+at\right) + v_i}{2} = \frac{2 v_i + at}{2} = v_i + \frac{1}{2}at $$
$$ d = v_i t + \frac{1}{2} a t^2 $$
Third equation: equation of (Displacement–Velocity)

We know that average velocity \(𝒗\) is given by the relation :

$$ \bar{v}=\frac{d}{t} \hspace{1cm} OR \hspace{1cm} \bar{v}=\frac{v_f+v_i}{2} $$ $$ \therefore d=\bar{v}t $$

From the first equation of motion,

$$ t=\frac{v_f-v_i}{a} $$ $$ \therefore d=\bar{v}t = \frac{v_f+v_i}{2} \times \frac{v_f-v_i}{a} = \frac{v_f^2 - v_i^2}{2a} $$
$$ 2ad = v_f^2 - v_i^2 $$

title: Free Fall - Vertical Projectiles
caption: Understand the physics of free fall and vertical projectiles, where gravity is the only force acting on an object in motion.
intro:
The great philosopher Aristotle stated that heavier objects fall faster than lighter ones, and this principle remained dominant for hundreds of years until the scientist Galileo came to test its validity, Galileo experimented with the Leaning Tower of Pisa by dropping objects with different weights, he observed that objects of different weights fell and hit the ground at the same time.

To understand the behavior of falling objects, we consider the simplest case which is the fall of objects under the influenceof their weight only. By neglecting the effect of air resistance,this motion is called free fall, and when air resistanceis neglected, all objects fall to the ground with the sameacceleration. This acceleration is called the free-fall acceleration.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:

  • know the acceleration of an object that undergoes a free fall.
  • be able to deduce the time required for an object to reach ground knowing the height.
  • be able to deduce the height from which an object falls from knowing the flight time
  • Know how an object moves if projected vertically.
  • Be able to deduce the required data of an object projected vertically.
details:
Free-fall acceleration
The constant rate at which objects move during free fall towards the surface of the Earth, and it is equal to \(𝟗.𝟖 𝐦/𝐬^𝟐\).


Equations of motion for an object undergoing a free-fall
$$ v_f = v_i + gt $$ $$ d=v_it + \frac{1}{2}gt^2 $$ $$ v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2gd $$

title: Two Dimensional Motion
caption: Explore the complexities of two-dimensional motion, focusing on how projectiles move when launched at an angle.
intro: The study of projectiles has contributed to the development of many weapons such as cannons, rifles, and others. We can divide projectiles into two types: vertical projectiles and projectiles at an angle.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:

  • know the acceleration of an object that undergoes a free fall.
  • be able to deduce the time required for an object to reach ground knowing the height.
  • be able to deduce the height from which an object falls from knowing the flight time
  • Know how an object moves if projected vertically.
  • Be able to deduce the required data of an object projected vertically.
details:
When a ball is projected upwards with initial velocity \(𝒗_𝒊\) at an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal, it moves in a curved path.

We can resolve velocity in two dimensions:

  • The horizontal dimension \(\left(𝒙\right)\)
    • The velocity of the ball is uniform \(𝒗_{𝒊𝒙}\), so : $$ v_{ix} = v_i \cos{\theta} $$
    • By substituting the value \(𝒗_{𝒊𝒙}\) in the three equations of motion where \(𝒂_𝒙=𝟎\), then: $$ v_{fx} = v_{ix} $$
  • The vertical dimension \(\left(y\right)\)
    • The ball moves at the acceleration due to gravity. Consequently, velocity varies. The initial vertical in the vertical dimension \(𝒗_{𝒊𝒚}\) is found by the relation: $$ v_{iy} = v_i \sin{\theta} $$
    • By substituting the value \(𝒗_{𝒊y}\) in the three equations of motion where \(𝒂_y=-g=-9.8\ m/s^2\), then \(v_f\) can be calculated.

Formulas

  • Finding the time of reaching the maximum height \(𝒕\):
    By substituting \(\left(𝒗_𝒇𝒚=𝟎\right)\) in the first equation of motion, we find: $$ t = \frac{-v_{iy}}{g} $$
  • Time taken till returning back to the plane (Flight time): $$ T = 2t = \frac{-2v_{iy}}{g}$$
  • Finding the maximum height reached by the projectile \(h\):
    By substituting \(\left(𝒗_𝒇𝒚=𝟎\right)\) in the third equation of motion, we find: $$ h = \frac{-v_{iy}^2}{2g} $$
  • Finding the horizontal range reached by the projectile \( \left(R\right) \):
    \(\because\) Time of the maximum horizontal range = Flight time = \(𝑻\)
    By substituting \(\left((𝒂_𝒙=𝟎\right)\) and \(\left(𝒅 = 𝑹\right)\) in the second equation of motion, we find: $$ R = v_{ix} T = 2 v_{ix} t = \dfrac{-2 v_{ix} v_{iy}}{g} $$

title: Force - Newton's First and Third Laws
caption: Examine the concepts of inertia and Newton's First and Third Laws, which describe the resistance to change in motion and action-reaction pairs.
intro: We have previously described motion by studying the concepts of velocity and acceleration without considering the objects' cases of motion, and in this chapter, we will study the effect of force on it.
goals:
At the end of this lesson, the student should:

  • Know how understanding forces is important in our day life.
  • Know how rockets, cars, and skateboards are working.
  • Know why some objects do not move.
  • Know what is inertia.
details:
Force: It is an external influence that affects the object to change its state of motion or direction.

  • Force is measured using the spring balance in Newton \(\left( 𝑵\right)\)

Newton summed up the concepts of force in three laws named after him called Newton's laws. We will cover two of them this semester and one next semester.

  • Newton’s first law
    • Definition:
      A static object keeps its state of rest, and a moving object keeps its state of motion at a uniform velocity in a straight line unless acted upon by a resultant force.
    • Formula : $$ \sum{F} = 0 $$
  • Inertia
    • Definition:
      It is the tendency of an object to keep either its state of rest or state of motion at its original velocity uniformly in straight line.

  • Newton’s third law
    • Definition:
      When an object acts on another object by a force, the second object reacts with an equal force on the first object in a direction opposite to that of action.
      Or:
      For every action there is a reaction equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

    • Formula : $$ \vec{F}_{12} = -\vec{F}_{21} $$

title: Momentum - Newton's Second Law
caption: Discover how momentum relates to force and acceleration, as described by Newton's Second Law of Motion.

title: Laws of Circular Motion
caption: Learn the principles governing circular motion, including the forces that keep objects moving in a curved path.

title: Universal Law of Gravitation
caption: Explore Newton's Universal Law of Gravitation, which explains how every mass attracts every other mass with a force proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

title: Gravitational Field
caption: Understand the concept of a gravitational field, the region of space surrounding a mass where another mass experiences a force of attraction.

title: Satellites
caption: Learn about the physics of satellites, including how they stay in orbit around Earth and other celestial bodies.

title: Work
caption: Examine the concept of work in physics, where force applied over a distance transfers energy to an object.

title: Energy
caption: Explore the various forms of energy, the capacity to do work, and how energy is transformed and conserved in physical systems.

title: Law of Conservation of Energy
caption: Understand the Law of Conservation of Energy, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.

title: Oscillatory Motion
caption: Learn the fundamentals of oscillatory motion, where objects move back and forth around an equilibrium position.

title: Wave Motion
caption: Explore how oscillatory motion propagates through space as waves, transferring energy without the movement of matter.

title: Properties of Light (Propagation, Reflection and Refraction)
caption: Uncover the basic properties of light as it travels, bounces off surfaces, and bends when passing through different materials.

title: Properties of Light (Interference and Diffraction)
caption: Understand the wave nature of light through phenomena like interference and diffraction, where light waves interact and create patterns.

title: Total Internal Reflection
caption: Explore the concept of total internal reflection, where light is completely reflected within a medium, leading to applications like fiber optics.

title: Deviation of Light in a Triangular Prism
caption: Learn how light bends and deviates when passing through a triangular prism, breaking down into its constituent colors.

title: Minimum Deviation in a Triangular Prism and Thin Prism
caption: Discover the conditions under which light experiences minimum deviation in a prism and the unique behaviors of thin prisms.

title: Fluid Flow
caption: Discover the principles governing the flow of fluids, including laminar and turbulent flow.

title: Viscosity
caption: Learn about viscosity, a measure of a fluid's resistance to flow, and its impact on fluid dynamics.

title: Density
caption: Understand the concept of density, which measures how much mass is packed into a given volume of a substance.

title: Pressure
caption: Learn about pressure, the force exerted per unit area, and its implications in both solids and fluids.

title: Pressure at a Point inside a Liquid
caption: Explore how pressure varies with depth within a liquid and the factors that influence it

title: Connected Vessels & U-Shaped Tube
caption: Discover how pressure equilibrium is maintained in connected vessels and U-shaped tubes, leading to practical applications in fluid systems.

title: Measuring Pressure (Mercury Barometer - Manometer)
caption: Learn about devices like the mercury barometer and manometer, used to measure atmospheric and fluid pressures.

title: Pascal's Principle
caption: Explore Pascal's Principle, which states that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions.

title: Properties of Gases and Boyle's Law
caption: Learn about the basic properties of gases and Boyle's Law, which describes the inverse relationship between pressure and volume.

title: Charles' Law
caption: Discover Charles' Law, which explains how the volume of a gas changes with temperature at constant pressure.

title: Pressure Law and General Gas Law
caption: Explore the Pressure Law and the General Gas Law, which combine to describe the behavior of gases under various conditions.

title: Electrical Current and Ohm's Law
caption: Explore the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance through Ohm's Law, the foundation of electrical circuits.

title: Resistors Connection
caption: Learn about different ways to connect resistors in series and parallel, and how these configurations affect the overall circuit.

title: Ohm's Law for the Closed Circuit
caption: Discover how Ohm's Law applies to complete circuits, including the role of internal resistance and voltage sources.

title: Kirchhoff's Laws
caption: Dive into Kirchhoff's Laws, which extend the analysis of complex circuits by balancing currents and voltages around loops and junctions.

title: Magnetic Effect of the Electric Current
caption: Learn how electric currents create magnetic fields and the principles behind electromagnetism.

title: Following of the Magnetic Effect of the Electric Current
caption: Continue exploring the magnetic effects of electric currents, including their applications in devices like electromagnets.

title: The Magnetic Force and the Torque
caption: Understand how magnetic forces act on current-carrying conductors, leading to torques and motion in devices like electric motors.

title: The Measuring Instruments
caption: Discover the instruments used to measure electrical and magnetic quantities, including ammeters, voltmeters, and galvanometers.

title: Faraday's Law - The Induced Electromotive Force Produced in a Straight Wire
caption: Explore Faraday's Law of Induction, explaining how moving a conductor through a magnetic field generates an electromotive force.

title: Mutual Induction between Two Coils - Self Induction of the Coil
caption: Learn about mutual induction, where changing currents in one coil induce currents in another, and self-induction, where a coil's changing current affects itself.

title: Electric Generator (Dynamo)
caption: Discover the principles behind electric generators (dynamos), which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy using electromagnetic induction.

title: The Electric Transformer - The Electric Motor
caption: Understand how transformers modify voltage levels in AC circuits and how electric motors convert electrical energy into mechanical motion.

title: Alternating Current Circuits
caption: Learn about the properties of AC circuits, including impedance, reactance, and power in resistive, capacitive, and inductive components.

title: Following AC Circuits
caption: Continue exploring AC circuits, focusing on phase relationships, power factor, and the role of resonance in circuit behavior.

title: The Oscillating Circuit - The Resonant Circuit
caption: Understand the principles of oscillating circuits and resonance, where specific frequencies maximize energy transfer in circuits.

title: Blackbody Radiation - Thermionic Effect and Photoelectric Effect
caption: Learn how blackbody radiation, the thermionic effect, and the photoelectric effect challenged classical physics and led to the development of quantum theory.

title: Compton Effect - Wave Particle Duality - Electron Microscope
caption: Discover the Compton effect, further evidence of wave-particle duality, and explore how this concept is applied in technologies like the electron microscope.

title: Atomic Spectra
caption: Explore how atoms emit and absorb light at specific wavelengths, creating atomic spectra that reveal the structure of atoms and energy levels.

title: Laser
caption: Discover how lasers work, the conditions required for their operation, and the diverse applications of coherent light in modern technology.

title: The Semiconductors Crystal - The pn Junction
caption: Learn about semiconductor crystals, the formation of pn junctions, and their crucial role in modern electronic devices.

title: The Transistor - Digital and Analog Electronics
caption: Discover how transistors function as the building blocks of digital and analog electronics, enabling everything from computers to communication systems.
